user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 2.1 is: A project shall not contain unreachable code.

</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of digest_reset:
```c
_MHD_static_inline void
digest_reset (struct DigestAlgorithm *da)
{
  mhd_assert (! da->uninitialised);
  mhd_assert (da->algo_selected);
  mhd_assert (! da->hashing);
#ifdef MHD_MD5_SUPPORT
  if (MHD_DIGEST_BASE_ALGO_MD5 == da->algo)
  {
#ifdef MHD_MD5_HAS_FINISH
    mhd_assert (! da->ready_for_hashing);
#else  /* ! MHD_MD5_HAS_FINISH */
    mhd_assert (da->ready_for_hashing);
#endif /* ! MHD_MD5_HAS_FINISH */
    MHD_MD5_reset (&da->ctx.md5_ctx);
#ifdef _DEBUG
    da->ready_for_hashing = true;
#endif /* _DEBUG */
  }
  else
#endif /* MHD_MD5_SUPPORT */
#ifdef MHD_SHA256_SUPPORT
  if (MHD_DIGEST_BASE_ALGO_SHA256 == da->algo)
  {
#ifdef MHD_SHA256_HAS_FINISH
    mhd_assert (! da->ready_for_hashing);
#else  /* ! MHD_SHA256_HAS_FINISH */
    mhd_assert (da->ready_for_hashing);
#endif /* ! MHD_SHA256_HAS_FINISH */
    MHD_SHA256_reset (&da->ctx.sha256_ctx);
#ifdef _DEBUG
    da->ready_for_hashing = true;
#endif /* _DEBUG */
  }
  else
#endif /* MHD_SHA256_SUPPORT */
#ifdef MHD_SHA512_256_SUPPORT
  if (MHD_DIGEST_BASE_ALGO_SHA512_256 == da->algo)
  {
    mhd_assert (! da->ready_for_hashing);
    MHD_SHA512_256_init (&da->ctx.sha512_256_ctx);
#ifdef _DEBUG
    da->ready_for_hashing = true;
#endif
  }
  else
#endif /* MHD_SHA512_256_SUPPORT */
  {
#ifdef _DEBUG
    da->ready_for_hashing = false;
#endif
    mhd_assert (0); /* May not happen, bad algorithm */
  }
}
```
</target_code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation: The suspicious fragments listed are the algorithm-selection branches (MD5, SHA256, SHA512_256) and the final fallback block. These are the locations most likely to contain unreachable code depending on compile-time configuration (the presence/absence of the MHD_*_SUPPORT macros) and on whether all possible values of da->algo are exhaustively handled. Other parts of the function do not need investigation for MISRA Rule 2.1: the initial mhd_assert checks at the top are simple runtime precondition checks and are reachable on function entry; the individual reset/init calls (MHD_MD5_reset, MHD_SHA256_reset, MHD_SHA512_256_init) are reached when the corresponding algorithm test is true and the corresponding support macro is defined; the _DEBUG-only assignments to da->ready_for_hashing are conditionally compiled and thus are not unreachable in builds where _DEBUG is defined; the inner HAS_FINISH/#else asserts are mutually exclusive conditional compilation directives and are executed only in the respective configurations. Therefore those other fragments do not present an obvious unreachable-code issue and need not be investigated for Rule 2.1.
